Chick-fil-A earns $8.5M per store. Subway? $500K. Here‚Äôs the thing franchise owners miss.

Chick-fil-A keeps tight control:¬†¬†
- Fewer stores (2,500 vs. Subway‚Äôs 20,000)
- Mandatory owner-operators (no absentee owners) ‚Äì if you own it, you‚Äôre in the restaurant¬†¬†¬†
- Prospective owners must have been Chick‚Äëfil‚ÄëA managers
- Real estate & build-out controlled by franchisor: They own the property and equipment, leasing it to you¬† ‚Äì¬† giving them full scope over site, design and brand consistency

Subway‚Äôs model?¬†
- Subway actively recruits owners to hold multi locations ‚Äì often 25+ units. This encourages passive investors who can oversee many units rather than deeply engage with individual restaurants.
- Franchisees lease and renovate their own real estate and choose their layouts‚Äîunlike Chick‚Äëfil‚ÄëA‚Äôs full franchisor-controlled build-out.
- Oversaturation ‚Üí cannibalization: Subway‚Äôs Average Unit Volume increased until 2013, then dropped sharply likely because stores placed too close to existing franchises were cannibalizing sales

The result?
Subway‚Äôs revenue peaked in 2013 and never recovered.
Chick-fil-a‚Äôs revenue has more than DOUBLED in the same period.

Chipotle spends more on ingredients than any fast-casual chain and it's become their biggest competitive advantage.

The high cost buys quality and a ton of quantity that drives orders.

Here's the breakdown of their average $18 check:

Revenue: $18
‚Ä¢ Food & packaging: $5.36 (29.8%)
‚Ä¢ Labor: $4.45 (24.7%)
‚Ä¢ Other operating: $2.50 (13.9%)
‚Ä¢ Occupancy: $0.92 (5.1%)

= $4.41 restaurant profit per transaction (24.5%)

At 480 transactions daily, that's $2,116 in profit per day. Annually: $772K per location.

What $5.36 buys:
‚Ä¢ Larger portions than competitors
‚Ä¢ 58% responsibly-sourced ingredients vs industry average of ~20%
‚Ä¢ Fresh produce delivered daily, no freezers in stores
‚Ä¢ Real cooking: chicken is grilled in-house, not pre-cooked
‚Ä¢ Transparent supply chain customers can verify

How volume makes it work:

Fixed costs dilute. The same occupancy cost spread over 480 transactions vs 200 transactions changes everything. Labor per transaction drops from $7 during slow hours to $2.50 during peak. Ingredient cost stays flat at $5.36 regardless of volume.

During lunch rush, their fastest restaurants hit 350 orders per hour, nearly 6 customers per minute. At that throughput, fixed costs become negligible.

This requires operational infrastructure that took years to build:
‚Ä¢ 350 orders/hour peak capacity (vs industry average of 100-120)
‚Ä¢ Digital ordering driving 35% of sales creating a second make-line
‚Ä¢ Chipotlane locations generating 15% higher volume
‚Ä¢ Supply chain that can handle fresh daily deliveries at scale

Competitors can't just "spend more on ingredients" and win. They need the volume first, which requires brand strength, digital infrastructure, and operational excellence that takes years to develop.

Fast-casual bowl chains are all dealing with the same pressures right now. Consumer spending down, food costs up, labor expensive. Here's how different chains are handling it.

In Q2 2025, the cracks are showing. Chipotle's same-store sales dropped -4%. Cava fell to 2.1% growth, down from 21% earlier in the year. Sweetgreen declined -7.6%.

All three generate similar revenue per location:
‚Ä¢ Cava: $2.9 million annually
‚Ä¢ Sweetgreen: $2.8 million annually
‚Ä¢ Chipotle: $3.2 million annually

Same volume. Different survival rates.

The difference shows up in operating efficiency.

Restaurant-level operating margins (Q2 2025):
‚Ä¢ Chipotle: 27.4%
‚Ä¢ Cava: 26.3%
‚Ä¢ Sweetgreen: 18.9%

That 7.4-point margin gap between Cava and Sweetgreen on similar revenue is everything. Both are fast-casual chains selling $16-24 bowls to similar customer demographics. Both face the same cost pressures. But Cava extracts $74,000 more profit per million dollars of revenue.

At their respective volumes, that's roughly $215,000 more profit per Cava restaurant annually. Across 398 Cava locations versus 260 Sweetgreen locations, the difference compounds.

Where it shows up:

Occupancy costs as percentage of revenue (Q2 2025):
‚Ä¢ Chipotle: ~5.0%
‚Ä¢ Cava: 6.8%
‚Ä¢ Sweetgreen: 8.9%

Occupancy includes rent, utilities, and related expenses. The 2.1-point gap between Cava and Sweetgreen reflects a combination of real-estate strategy (urban vs suburban mix, unit size, drive-thru capability) and operational leverage in extracting revenue from each square foot.

At $2.9 million annual revenue, a 2.1-point occupancy cost difference equals roughly $61,000 per location annually.

Labor costs (Q2 2025):
‚Ä¢ Chipotle: 24.7%
‚Ä¢ Cava: 25.0%
‚Ä¢ Sweetgreen: 27.5%

Food, beverage & packaging costs (Q2 2025):
‚Ä¢ Chipotle: 28.9%
‚Ä¢ Cava: 29.4%
‚Ä¢ Sweetgreen: 27%

These cost structure differences compound at scale. The 7.4-point margin gap translates to roughly $207,000 less profit per Sweetgreen location annually compared to Cava.

When same-store sales growth turns negative, these gaps matter. A 2% decline in traffic at Cava's margins is survivable. At Sweetgreen's margins, it's a crisis.

The chart shows everyone declining. But declining from 26.3% margins versus 18.9% margins determines who survives the next 12 months.

Business 101 says you should focus on one thing but Cheesecake Factory serves pasta, burgers, salads, Asian food, AND cheesecake. It has 7,200% growth in 32 years.

250 items made fresh from scratch, catering to every customer type. Families, business dinners, date nights, health-conscious diners. They captured every occasion.

And this worked with the numbers to back it up -> $50M to $3.6B in revenue. 15% compound annual growth for three decades. While restaurant chains struggled to scale past $500M, Cheesecake Factory quietly built a multi-billion dollar empire.

They own two bakery facilities. While other restaurant chains buy desserts from third-party suppliers, Cheesecake Factory makes their own. They control quality, costs, and supply chain from production to plate. This helps them control margins.

Their expansion strategy is equally smart. They picked high-profile mall locations when everyone said "malls are dead." and worked on Middle East licensing deals that actually worked. 

Cheesecake Factory carries a high debt load, which some view as risk. However, leverage is supported by strong EBITDA and cash flow. The company‚Äôs balance sheet suggests it is not over-leveraged but pursuing an aggressive growth strategy

The company did not narrow its focus to a single product line. Instead, its strategy centered on building a diversified restaurant portfolio rather than relying solely on cheesecake.

I walked around San Francisco for 6 months to build my company.

Year 1 of Superorder. No customers. No proven model. All I had was just an idea that restaurants needed help.

So I went door to door to restaurants across SF, trying to convince owners to let me create virtual brands for them.

I learned that rejection builds resilience faster than any book. 

Most doors got slammed. But each "no" made the next conversation easier.
The best customers become friends. 

Pizza Inferno was one of my first closes. I'd visit every other week just to hang out.

While competitors built fancy presentations, I had real conversations with real operators.

Those first 30 restaurants from going door to door became the foundation for everything that followed.

Sometimes the best growth hack is just showing up and doing things that don't scale.

Even today, we still show up. Henry Engel, Vamsi Gadiraju, and I flew to a major client, demoed face-to-face and addressed all the questions key decision makers had.

When you work with Superorder, you bet on world class customer service - we show up everyday even in person.

The biggest American QSRs reported their Q2 earnings last week. Things are not looking good.

Amid the chaos, here are the restaurants that stood out:
¬†
- Chilis: $10 ‚Äú3 for Me‚Äù deal drove +21% traffic YoY; TurboChef ovens cut cook times 40‚Äì50%; 25% menu reduction focused on four items (burgers, crispers, fajitas, margs) now 47% of sales.

- Taco Bell: Record digital mix (41% of sales) and loyalty up 45% YoY; LTOs and $5‚Äì$9 value boxes drove broad traffic gains.

- Domino‚Äôs: Carryout up +5.8% to record highs; delivery +1.5% aided by DoorDash/Uber. Parmesan-Stuffed Crust boosted traffic

Everyone else seems to be having a rough time.

The reality is that same-store sales growth is hard to sustain in a tightening market

DoorDash went from posting just $123M in net income to delivering $478M in profit in the first half of 2025.

They posted three straight quarters of losses in 2024, before finally turning a $117M operating profit in Q4. However in that quarter, they spent $541M on marketing to earn the profit, and half of their $2.87B in revenue ($1.45B) was consumed by cost of revenues. 

2025 first half: $6.3B revenue, $478M profit. Three consecutive quarters of 13%+ profit margins.

This wasn't a one-off success - they focused on their unit economics. 

Every order cost $8-10 to deliver. Customer acquisition cost $53. Restaurants took 15-30% commissions. Scale made the problem bigger, not smaller.

DoorDash fixed it with five changes:

1. Take-rate enhancements. They increased average commission per order, improving contribution margins on core delivery.

2. DashPass scale. 22+ million subscribers (up from 18M), driving recurring revenue and higher order frequency.

3. Advertising platform. DoorDash Ads hit $1B+ annualized revenue run rate by the end of 2024. High-margin revenue stream.

4. Operational efficiency. Algorithmic routing and logistics optimization reduced per-order fulfillment costs.

5. Cost discipline. Better marketing spend management and driver incentive controls as percentage of revenue.

The new economics work. Revenue per order increased, recurring subscription revenue grew, and high-margin advertising revenue expanded while technology-driven optimization lowered fulfillment costs.

Q2 2025: $3.3B revenue, $285M net income. Marketing spend: $607M. They're spending 2x their profit on marketing but still making money.

YC told me our idea sucked.

Week 0 of the batch ‚Äì we were wrangling the math of ghost kitchens

How do you tell Dalton Caldwell you just torched your own thesis?

He didn‚Äôt flinch.

‚ÄúYeah, obviously it sucks. What else can you build?‚Äù

Hundreds of customer interviews later, we kept hearing the same pain: reviews, rankings, and repeat business slipping through the cracks.

Those conversations led us first to Forward Kitchens and then eventually to Superorder.

AI-powered reputation management to dominate local search and ratings: more foot traffic, more deliveries, more revenue

Listening to our customers and abandoning our haughty beliefs led us to the truth: The biggest problem wasn‚Äôt in the kitchen ‚Äì it surfaced hours before, when a user typed ‚Äúchinese food near me, open now‚Äù and looked for the best rated restaurants.

If that sounds interesting, I‚Äôd love to tell you more.

If you‚Äôre running a multi-location restaurant brand and want to stay ahead of your reviews -- we‚Äôre here to help. Let‚Äôs chat.

Jack in the Box selling Del Taco for $115M marks the latest casualty in restaurant conglomerate M&A, a space where 70-75% of deals fail.

Jack in the Box's multi-brand experiment cost shareholders 75% of market value. From $1.41B market cap in 2022 to $0.36B today, while carrying $3.13B in debt.

The execution timeline:

2003-2018: The Qdoba Era
‚Ä¢ Acquired for $45M (2003)
‚Ä¢ 15 years of integration attempts
‚Ä¢ Sold to Apollo for $305M (2018) - rare M&A win
‚Ä¢ Lesson ignored: focus beats diversification

2022: The Del Taco Gamble
‚Ä¢ Acquired for $585M (March)
‚Ä¢ Integration synergies promised
‚Ä¢ Reality: separate supply chains, different customer bases
‚Ä¢ Del Taco same-store sales: -3.9% by Q3 2024

2025: The Unwinding
‚Ä¢ Del Taco sale: ~$115M (80% loss)
‚Ä¢ Store closures: 80-120 locations
‚Ä¢ Dividend suspended
‚Ä¢ Debt reduction becomes survival priority

Meanwhile, focused operators print money:
‚Ä¢ Chick-fil-A: $9.3M average unit volume
‚Ä¢ In-N-Out: $5.8M average unit volume¬†¬†
‚Ä¢ Five Guys: $1.5M average unit volume
‚Ä¢ Jack in the Box + Del Taco combined: <$2.5M

The pattern is clear across the industry. Red Lobster, TGI Fridays, Lemonade, all casualties of the same playbook. Debt-funded acquisitions ‚Üí integration failures ‚Üí fire sales.

In restaurants, operational excellence doesn't transfer between brands. Each concept requires distinct capabilities, from supply chain to service culture. Multi-brand portfolios multiply complexity without multiplying returns.

Remote work is not serious work. 

During COVID, we tried remote like everyone else. When offices reopened, we decided to try staying remote for about a year since the team had gotten comfortable around it. 

I learned that communication gaps are almost impossible to fully close when you‚Äôre building a startup remotely. 

In-person, you turn to your teammate, hash something out in two minutes, and move forward. Remotely, that same problem becomes a 30-minute scheduled call, or worse, a Slack thread that drags for days. 

The casual interactions also create culture. Shared meals, jokes, whiteboard sessions - that‚Äôs where people actually buy into the mission. When you‚Äôre remote, you can onboard someone and run team calls, but it‚Äôs harder for them to feel what the company is about. 

And at minimum - the core team has to be in person. In the early days, it‚Äôs not optional. That‚Äôs when every conversation matters. Maybe some non-exec roles can be remote here and there, but the preference should still be in-person.

Yes, a handful of companies like Zapier have made remote work. But they‚Äôre the exception, not the rule. Most startups simply bleed speed, culture, and execution when they try. 

If you‚Äôre trying to build something fast, something ambitious - remote work is definitely not the move.

In the 1960s, McDonald‚Äôs first non-burger menu item (Filet-O-Fish) went head-to-head with a grilled pineapple sandwich - and the story only gets weirder from there.

üìâ In the early 1960s, Cincinnati McDonald‚Äôs franchisee Lou Groen faced a crisis. A massive portion of his Monfort Heights customers were Catholic, and every Friday during Lent, they abstained from meat (except fish). Sales were down.

Groen noticed a nearby Frisch‚Äôs Big Boy selling plenty of fish sandwiches. So he made his own and pitched it to McDonald‚Äôs founder Ray Kroc.

Kroc‚Äôs reaction?¬† ‚ÄúHell no‚Äù Kroc said he didn‚Äôt care if the Pope himself showed up, he could eat a burger just like everyone else.

üçç But Groen persisted and Kroc agreed ‚Äì on one condition. The Filet-O-Fish would face off against his own meatless creation: the Hula Burger, a grilled pineapple-and-cheese sandwich.

The showdown was set for Good Friday, 1962. The winner stays on the menu.
Groen crushed it ‚Äì selling 350 Filet-O-Fish sandwiches that day and only 6 Hula burgers

The ‚Äúfish that catches people‚Äù went from a Friday-only offering to a daily menu item, then regional, national, and global. It was the first non-burger on McDonald‚Äôs original menu ‚Äì joining other franchisee inventions like the Big Mac, Egg McMuffin, and apple pie.

For Groen, it was life-changing. After losing his home and nearly going broke, he rebuilt from scratch ‚Äì turning one struggling store into¬† 40+ McDonald‚Äôs locations!

üöÄ Today, McDonald‚Äôs sells 300 million Filet-O-Fish sandwiches a year. Nearly every major fast-food chain now runs special Lent menus: Wendy‚Äôs, Arby‚Äôs, KFC, Jack in the Box,Carl‚Äôs Jr., Taco Bell, and more.

The Filet-O-Fish also changed McDonald‚Äôs corporate DNA ‚Äì forcing it to consider the diversity of American markets. A blue polystyrene clamshell Filet-O-Fish box sits in the National Museum of American History.

Kroc famously quipped to two Catholic executives: ‚ÄúNow that we‚Äôve invested in all this equipment to handle fish, the pope will change the rules.‚Äù

Wingstop made it more expensive to open a store and growth accelerated.

Franchise buy-in jumped $145K between 2019 and 2024. In that same period, they grew from 1,385 to 2,214 locations.

2019: The Starting Point
‚Ä¢ Franchise cost: $390K
‚Ä¢ SEC filing: "We target a franchisee return of approximately 35% to 40%"
‚Ä¢ Average sales per location: $1.2M/year
‚Ä¢ 1,313 locations

2020: Proof of Concept
‚Ä¢ Average sales per location: $1.5M (delivery boom)
‚Ä¢ 94% of new locations opened by existing franchisees
‚Ä¢ Royalty revenue: $108.9M

2021-2023: The Price Climb
‚Ä¢ Franchise cost rises: $400K ‚Üí $480K
‚Ä¢ SEC filing updates promise: "We target a franchisee return of approximately 50%+"
‚Ä¢ Average sales per location: $1.8M by 2023
‚Ä¢ 90%+ of expansion still from existing franchisees

2024: The Result
‚Ä¢ Franchise cost: $535K (37% higher than 2019)
‚Ä¢ Average sales per location: $2.1M (75% higher than 2019)
‚Ä¢ 2,165 locations
‚Ä¢ Royalty revenue: $259.6M (5.6x growth since 2015)

The counterintuitive part: raising the franchise fee didn't slow expansion because Wingstop simultaneously engineered the conditions that made each location more profitable. A higher upfront cost became acceptable when the annual returns grew even faster.

Here's how they increased sales per location without owning the stores:

‚Ä¢ Marketing: Forced franchisees to contribute 5.3% of sales to an advertising fund (up from 4% in 2019). More ads = more customers.

‚Ä¢ Digital ordering: Built the app and website. By 2020, 60% of orders were digital. Franchisees didn't build the tech but got the sales.

‚Ä¢ Real estate: Shifted from urban dine-in to suburban drive-thru. Lower rent, higher takeout volume.

‚Ä¢ Supply chain: With 2,000+ locations, Wingstop negotiated discounts with suppliers and collected rebates ($17.7M in 2023). Pure profit.

‚Ä¢ Menu: Wings, fries, sides. Simple menu = lower labor costs = higher margins for franchisees.

Between 2019-2021, over 90% of new locations were opened by franchisees who already owned Wingstops. If the economics didn't work, they wouldn't expand.

Wingstop added 1,339 franchised locations from 2015-2024. They only added 31 company-owned stores. They let franchisees take the risk of opening stores while collecting guaranteed 6% royalties on every dollar sold.

Dutch Bros went public in 2021 and raised $600M. Most chains would use that to franchise aggressively. Dutch Bros did the opposite.

2021: 50% company-operated
2024: 68% company-operated

They're buying back control, not selling it.

The franchise model is a financial arbitrage. You trade operational control for capital efficiency.

Dunkin collects 5.9% of every dollar a franchisee makes. That's $76K per shop in royalties to corporate.

The franchisee keeps the rest. They pay for everything, take all operating risk. Dunkin just collects the check.

Cost to Dunkin to collect that $76K? Almost nothing. That royalty stream has a ~90% profit margin.

Scale across 9,850 locations: hundreds of millions in high-margin revenue. No real estate risk, no labor, no capital required.

The trade-off? Speed.

Test a new menu item? Regional meetings, pilot programs, legal approvals. 3-6 months minimum.

Franchisees own their stores and optimize for their P&L, not your brand strategy. Manager quits (55% turnover)? Sales drop 13-17%. That's the franchisee's problem.

The franchise model turns restaurants into a royalty-collection business. High margin, low control, slow iteration.

Dutch Bros chose the opposite trade-off.

When you own the stores, you control the feedback loop.

Test a new drink at 50 shops. Roll it out to all 670 company stores in 2-4 weeks. No approvals. No negotiations.

Manager turnover drops to 35% because you're hiring for yourself, not franchisees who cut corners.

Every operational improvement compounds immediately. New training program? All stores next week. Better scheduling? Deployed in days.

The cost? You fund everything. Your EBITDA margin is 16% instead of 90%. Your ROIC is 5.07% instead of 30%+. You grow to 982 locations instead of 9,850.

But your improvement cycles are 10x faster.

Franchising compounds financial returns. High margins, no capital, exponential unit growth.

Operating compounds operational returns. Every improvement feeds back immediately. Store 670 benefits from learnings at store 1.

Dutch Bros chose to accelerate the operational flywheel, not the financial one.

Between 2021-2024, they grew company-operated stores 147%. Franchised stores? Only 17%.

They're not just preferring one model. They're actively converting from one to the other.

Dunkin: 90% margin on $76K = $68K profit per shop
Dutch Bros: 16% margin on $2M = $320K profit per shop

In 90 days, Chipotle lost 50% of its value and sickened customers in 11 states. Now they set the industry's food safety standards.

The E. coli outbreak started in October 2015. Contaminated produce likely lettuce or tomatoes spread bacteria through Chipotle locations from Washington to Ohio. 55 customers fell ill. 21 ended up in hospitals. The CDC launched a criminal investigation that would last years.

Stock price: $750 ‚Üí $400 (47% crash)
Market cap: $14.67 billion ‚Üí $7.2 billion (lost more than their annual revenue)
Same-store sales: -23.4% by Q1 2016
Revenue: Down 13.3% year-over-year

One in four customers stopped coming. 43 locations shut down. Wall Street analysts declared the brand permanently damaged.

Instead of damage control, they hired Mansour Samadpour, the food safety expert who'd revolutionized testing protocols at Costco and Jack in the Box. His audit revealed uncomfortable truths about their "fresh food" supply chain.

They implemented DNA-based testing on every ingredient. Not random samples. Every batch. Over 100 tests per ingredient before it reached stores.

They started blanching onions in boiling water. Marinating chicken in sealed bags. Testing lettuce at three different points. Changes that horrified their "fresh is everything" culture.

The losses continued. Q3 2016: same-store sales still down -21.9%. 

December 2016:

Same-store sales jumped +14.7%. The first positive number in 14 months. Customers were returning.

McDonald's quietly adopted Chipotle's enhanced produce washing protocols. Qdoba implemented DNA testing. Subway overhauled their handling procedures. Panera launched nationwide safety training programs.

By 2023, Chipotle hit $9.9 billion in revenue, 2.5x their crisis low. The same analysts who predicted their demise now studied their comeback.

The $25 million criminal fine they paid in 2020? A rounding error compared to the $8 billion in shareholder value they'd rebuilt.

Chipotle didn't just fix their food safety problem. They set a standard so high that the entire industry had to follow. Their biggest failure became their moat.

Matcha grew 4,300% since 2008. Drip coffee barely moved.

I pulled 16 years of Google Trends data:

‚Ä¢ Matcha: 1 ‚Üí 43 (4,300% growth)
‚Ä¢ Cold brew: 0 ‚Üí 8 (1,000% growth from zero)
‚Ä¢ Cappuccino: 4 ‚Üí 14 (250% steady growth)
‚Ä¢ Americano: 32 ‚Üí 44 (peaked at 100 in 2010, now declining)
‚Ä¢ Latte: 5 ‚Üí 58 (1,060% growth, but plateaued)
‚Ä¢ Drip coffee: 0 ‚Üí 2 (barely moved)

Two things happened.

Health benefits drove adoption. Matcha has L-theanine for focus without jitters, plus antioxidants that beat most fruits. 

Social media amplified the trend. Matcha‚Äôs vibrant green color popped on Instagram and TikTok, while drip coffee‚Äôs brown looked dull.

The market exploded. The global matcha market hit $3.84 billion in 2024, growing faster than coffee overall. Starbucks charges $5+ for matcha drinks. People pay it.

Drip coffee dominated American coffee culture for 50+ years. It's now flatlining.

Consumers reward products that work for them and look good doing it. That‚Äôs the new benchmark.

Last month the Superorder team went out to celebrate a major deal we signed.

Most of our growth so far has happened through Slack pings, late-night calls, and high-stakes meetings - the kind that stretch you but also bond you. Taking everyone out felt like a well-earned pause.

The same energy that drives code commits, campaign launches, and customer wins came alive in person. The small jokes. The shared stories. The sense of ‚Äúwe‚Äôre in this together.‚Äù

Moments like these tighten the culture and make the company feel smaller - in the best way.

Team outings aren‚Äôt about dinners or activities. They‚Äôre about humanizing the work. About turning colleagues into people you actually want to win with.

$20,000 robots are about to replace entire restaurant kitchen staffs.

And most restaurant owners aren't ready for it.

The reality of automated QSRs might be closer than we imagine.

Big names like Sweetgreen and Chipotle are already testing automated food prep lines in their kitchens.

When robots can make a $9 bowl that used to cost $14, it'll shake up the entire restaurant business.

Small restaurant owners will have the same opportunities as large chains. The advantage of having deep pockets will matter less as robot solutions become available to everyone.

In this new competitive environment, success will come down to two things:
- Brand identity (think clean ingredients, no processed oils, healthy options)
- Unique recipes that create memorable flavors

Store location will still count. But the rules change when robots handle the cooking and prep work.

Here's what I wonder: Will we reach a point where having food prepared by actual people becomes something special? Something we pay extra for?

Like handcrafted vs mass-produced.
Human vs machine.

Sweetgreen is in a tough spot right now

But they‚Äôre holding a move that could flip the game overnight.

Losses are deepening, same-store sales are down, and customer traffic is eroding in key markets. But there‚Äôs a bright spot: The Infinite Kitchen.

Sweetgreen‚Äôs Q2 2025 results paint a challenging picture:

üìâ $23.2M net loss, up from $14.5M a year ago.
üìâ 7.6% drop in same-store sales ‚Äì their second consecutive quarterly decline (but H1 2025 has been down for the industry overall)
üìâ 6.5% fall in customer traffic, especially in core urban markets like NYC, LA, and Boston.
üìâ Operational margin sliding to ‚Äì14.2% from ‚Äì8.8% last year, weighed down by menu complexity and high overhead.

Operationally, things were also tough:
Loyalty program transition ‚Äì from Sweetpass to a new points-based SG Rewards ‚Äì disrupted buying patterns: fewer repeat visits from regular customers.
Distractions from the short-lived Ripple Fries launch (discontinued after a few months)

But their Infinite Kitchen pilot locations show signs of promise

These automated, AI-powered kitchens are delivering ~28% store-level margins ‚Äì a meaningful jump from the chain‚Äôs typical 18‚Äì22% range.

If you look at the chart below (indexed to a ~$16 bowl):
$16.00 in revenue¬†
$12.86 in restaurant operating costs
Leaves:

McDonald's fries are the best fries in the world.

Belgian frites, artisan hand-cut fries, Five Guys, In-N-Out, none of them come close to what McDonald's delivers.

In 1961, shortly after acquiring McDonald's, Ray Kroc did something unusual: he built an R&D lab dedicated entirely to perfecting french fries.

Kroc believed fries were McDonald's strategic differentiator. He saw them as more important than anything else on the menu because they symbolized what the brand stood for: quality, consistency, and reliability.

He treated fry preparation like a "sacred ritual." When fries didn't meet his standards, bland, mushy, inconsistent he considered it a failure. He'd reject entire batches and demand his suppliers start over.

That obsession led to something no competitor has been able to replicate: an end-to-end system that processes 3.4 billion pounds of potatoes annually.

Here's what makes it work:

‚Ä¢ Potato sourcing: McDonald's only uses Russet Burbank potatoes from ~100 suppliers worldwide. Each supplier goes through a rigorous approval process for size, shape, texture, and storability.

‚Ä¢ The double-fry method: Fries are par-fried at 335¬∞F for exactly 3 minutes and 10 seconds at the supplier level, then flash-frozen to lock in texture. In stores, they're fried again at the same precise temperature and time.

‚Ä¢ Scale and precision: Every step from blanching (12-25 minutes) to coating with potato starch to shaking the basket 3-4 times during frying is standardized across 40,000+ locations.

The result? They've mastered consistency at scale. 3.6 billion servings a year across 40,000+ locations, zero variation.

McDonald's has spent 60+ years optimizing supplier relationships, proprietary equipment, and logistics networks. Their vertical integration and economies of scale create cost advantages that competitors simply can't replicate.

Five Guys, Shake Shack, In-N-Out: they all make great fries. But they don't have the decades of R&D, the supplier infrastructure, or the operational scale to match McDonald's consistency.

Fast food went from the highest value score (8.0 out of 10) in America to the lowest (5.2) in just 5 years. The tables have completely turned.

YouGov BrandIndex measures consumer value perception on a 0-10 scale. Fast food: 8.0 (2019) ‚Üí 5.2 (2024). Casual dining: 6.7 (2019) ‚Üí 7.7 (2024) now highest.

The math doesn't add up. Fast food prices increased 22% over 5 years. Casual dining prices increased 34% over the same period. Yet casual dining maintained value perception while fast food collapsed.

Fast food broke the social contract of being cheap.

When McDonald's raises prices from $5 to $7, it feels like a 40% increase. When Olive Garden raises prices from $15 to $18, it feels like normal inflation. The psychology of pricing matters more than the math.

The data shows this clearly. Fast food menu prices increased 42% from 2020-2025, with some chains up to 82%. The result? McDonald's same-store sales are up by just 2.5% in Q2 2025.

But here's what happened to casual dining chains: They're thriving. Chili's same-store sales are up by 14.1% in Q1 2024. Olive Garden is up by 6.9% in Q4 2023.

Fast food's core value proposition was "cheap and convenient." When prices crept up, it broke the fundamental contract. Consumers started trading down to cheaper menu items or walking away entirely.

Casual dining's value proposition was always "experience and atmosphere." They could raise prices because consumers expected to pay more for the full experience.

Fast food raised prices less (22%) but lost value perception completely. Casual dining raised prices more (34%) but maintained their value advantage.

In 2015, Danny Meyer ran a crazy experiment and removed tipping at his restaurants. 

But only 5 years later he reversed it. 

Here's what happened.

Union Square Hospitality Group was supposed to prove no-tipping could work in America. Meyer ran 18 restaurants including Union Square Cafe and Gramercy Tavern. If anyone could pull this off, it was him.

The plan looked solid on paper:
- Raise menu prices 15-20%
- Pay servers consistent hourly wages
- Call it "Hospitality Included"
- Close the pay gap between servers and kitchen staff

The media went wild. Eater said it would "save the hospitality industry" and "forever change how diners dine." The New York Times predicted "nothing will ever be the same."

But things didn't go according to plan.

Servers at Maialino and Gramercy Tavern saw their pay drop $100 per week. One server at Union Square Cafe lost $10,000 annually. 

The restaurant group hemorrhaged front-of-house staff. Meyer admitted they lost 40% of their servers. His chief restaurant officer said "our strongest people have left."

Why? Servers could make more money with tips from competitors. 

Meanwhile, the business costs exploded:
- Payroll taxes tripled at some restaurants¬†¬†
- Insurance costs increased significantly
- Menu price resistance from customers
- No federal tax advantages (tips get tax breaks, wages don't)

In 2020, he reversed the policy during the pandemic, saying it was "inhumane to tell our servers that you can't accept that expression of gratitude."

The experiment wasn't isolated. Nearly 90% of restaurants that tried no-tipping switched back. Some lasted only six months.

The experiment revealed 3 hard truths about tipping:
1. Servers don't want predictable wages if it means lower total income. Tips let high performers earn more than their base wage. Take that away, and your best people leave.
2. Diners resist paying higher menu prices even when told it eliminates tipping. A $28 entree feels expensive. A $24 entree plus a $5 tip feels normal, even though it's more money.
3. The tax system favors tipping. Tips get federal tax breaks that wages don't. Switch to wages, and your payroll taxes can triple overnight.

His experiment proved tipping survives because it works for everyone customers, servers, and operators even when everyone admits it's flawed.

Din Tai Fung's flagship locations generate $27.4 million per restaurant annually.

That's not from premium pricing alone. It's from how fixed costs scale at high revenue levels.

Average check: $45 per person. With average parties of 3.5 people, that's $158 per table.

Operating 7 days a week with extended hours through late-night service.

What $27.4 million actually requires:

$75,000 in revenue. Every single day.

$75,000 √∑ $158 = 475 parties daily. Or roughly 1,660 individual covers.

To hit that number, you need 6-7 full table turns across lunch, dinner, and late-night service. Not just on weekends. Every day.

This is where fixed costs matter:

Take rent. A prime Times Square location costs roughly $2 million annually.

At $27.4M revenue: rent is 7.3% of revenue.
At $15M revenue: rent becomes 13.3% of revenue.

Same rent payment. But it consumes nearly double the revenue as a percentage.

This pattern repeats across every fixed cost: utilities, insurance, management overhead. Higher revenue spreads these costs over a larger base. Each dollar of fixed cost becomes proportionally cheaper per sale.

That's fixed cost leverage.

But revenue doesn't equal profit:

Restaurant-level operating margin (industry estimates): 12-15%

At $27.4M, Din Tai Fung generates ~$3.3-4.1M profit per location.

Why margins stay at 12-15% despite massive revenue: hand-folded dumplings and full-service dining eat into margins that drive-thru or counter-service models can preserve.

The fragility of high-volume models:

At 475 parties per day, fixed costs sit at 10-12% of revenue. The model prints money.

Drop to 300 parties per day a 37% decline in traffic and those same fixed costs jump to 16-19% of revenue. Margins compress toward zero.

The rent doesn't change. The utilities don't change. The insurance doesn't change. But revenue drops, so fixed costs become a larger percentage of what's left.

Large footprints in prime locations mean fixed costs don't flex down when volume drops. You either run at capacity and win, or run at 60% and bleed.

Din Tai Fung built a model that's incredibly profitable when busy and fragile when it's not. Fixed costs are a weapon when you have volume.

Here's the story of how the In-N-Out founder invented the $200B+ drive-thru industry that every chain uses today. Also crazy that 70% of all fast food sales happen via drive-thrus ü§Ø.

It was a combination of California car culture, post-war suburbanization, and Harry Snyder tinkering in his Baldwin Park garage at night in 1948.

When Harry Snyder opened his tiny burger stand that year, most fast food still involved getting out of your car. You'd either walk up to a counter or wait for carhops to bring food on trays.

Over the previous decades, car culture had been building momentum in Southern California. Drive-in theaters were popular. The Pig Stand in Texas (1921) had carhops serving food in cars. But it was slow and labor-intensive.

Harry Snyder founded In-N-Out Burger with his wife Esther, and their burger stand was tiny (10 feet wide) and focused on fresh ingredients. But the real innovation happened after hours.

Snyder spent his nights in his garage engineering a two-way speaker system that would let customers order from their cars without face-to-face interaction.

Two features of 1940s California helped make this work:
- Geography: Post-war suburban design meant restaurants needed to serve cars, not pedestrians. Wide parking lots and street access became essential.
- Technology: Radio technology was advancing fast. Snyder could build an intercom system that actually worked reliably.

Fast forward to the 1950s: other chains started copying In-N-Out's system. Jack-in-the-Box added a mascot voice on their intercom. Wienerschnitzel joined in 1961.

But the real explosion came in the 1970s when McDonald's perfected the franchise model and spread drive-thrus nationwide.

The design was ideal for America's changing lifestyle. Suburbanization meant longer commutes. Two-income households meant less time for sit-down meals. Drive-thrus solved the speed problem without sacrificing convenience.

Fast food had always been about efficiency, but many people wanted something even faster than walking inside and waiting in line.

Just pull up, order through a speaker, pay at one window, get food at another.

That little speaker system Harry Snyder built in his garage became a $200 billion industry standard.

In order to grow a restaurant chain quickly you need a shit ton of capital. And restaurant chains use this hack called sale leasebacks to unlock that capital. 

Most restaurants are sitting on a goldmine: their real estate. The smartest operators are turning that real estate into capital without losing control of their business. 

A sale leaseback is when a restaurant sells its owned real estate to an investor, then immediately leases it back under a long-term agreement. That unlocks cash while letting the restaurant keep operating in the same location.

How are some recent examples of groups using this to grow:

üçî Meritage Hospitality (2nd-largest Wendy‚Äôs franchisee) sold 48 stores in 2020‚Äì21 for $109M, using the proceeds to build new units and pay down credit lines.

üçï Papa John‚Äôs (2024) sold two commissary kitchens for $46.7M with 17-year triple-net leases and 2.75% annual rent bumps. That plugged a $27M cash shortfall and booked a $41M gain.

üçó Yummy Inc. (a large Yum! Brands franchisee) recapitalized 20 Taco Bell & KFC units this way, stabilizing operations and funding growth within a year.

üçü Red Robin sold 28 sites for ~$73M in 2023‚Äì24 to Essential Properties Realty Trust, cutting debt by $49M in one year.

Why investors love QSR (quick-service restaurant) real estate:

1Ô∏è‚É£ E-commerce resistant ‚Äì You can‚Äôt ‚ÄúAmazon‚Äù a burger. Even during the pandemic, drive-thru and takeout kept revenue flowing and rent paid. Compare that with malls and shopping real-estate that‚Äôs been hammered as consumers buy entirely online

2Ô∏è‚É£ Triple-net stability ‚Äì Tenants pay property taxes, utilities, insurance, and common area fees. Landlords collect rent (often with 1‚Äì2% annual bumps) without worrying about other costs

3Ô∏è‚É£ Creditworthy tenants ‚Äì Corporate-guaranteed McDonald‚Äôs and Chick-fil-A sites have sold at 4.0‚Äì4.5% cap rates. That‚Äôs seen as lower risk than a mom-and-pop shop that could miss rent payments

Domino's doubled their debt and 4x'd their stock price in 10 years.

They didn't open more stores. They didn't improve margins. They just divided the same profit by fewer shares.

Most restaurant chains own their stores. Domino's doesn't.

6,700+ U.S. locations are owned by franchisees. Domino's just collects 5.5% royalties.

Between 2015-2024, operating cash flow went from $292M to $625M. Growth funded by franchisees, not Domino's.

Over 10 years, Domino's had $7.99B to deploy:

$5.25B from operations
$2.74B from new debt

Where it went: $5.90B to buybacks (73%), $1.22B to dividends (15%), $0.91B to the business (11%).

The result:

2015: 56 million shares, $3.47 EPS
2024: 34.28 million shares (-38.8%), $16.69 EPS (4.8x)

Operating income grew 12% annually. EPS grew 19.2% annually.

Domino's borrowed specifically to buy back stock. Each cycle: fewer shares ‚Üí higher EPS ‚Üí stock up ‚Üí cheaper debt ‚Üí repeat.

Debt went from $2.24B to $4.98B (122% growth). Most companies would call that risky.

But their ability to pay interest improved:

2017: $122.5M interest, $339M cash flow (2.8x)
2023: $196.5M interest, $590M cash flow (3.0x)

Cash flow grew faster than interest costs. Paying the debt became easier.

Why? Franchise royalties are contracted. No real estate risk. Low capital requirements. The business model made the debt predictable.

McDonald's has $51.9B in debt backed by real estate. Domino's has $5.0B backed by franchise cash flow. Different collateral, same logic.

The risk: if cash flow drops 20%, you still owe the debt. The shares you bought back don't come back.

They optimized for per-share returns over balance sheet safety.

2015: $2.24B debt, 56M shares
2024: $4.98B debt, 34.28M shares, stock price 4x higher

They turned a pizza franchise into a cash-flow royalty stream, then used debt to amplify the returns per share.

The hospitality businesses winning aren't the ones selling the most alcohol. They're the ones understanding how each generation wants to spend their money.

Why is Italian food so popular?

Italy has 59 million people, smaller than Thailand, smaller than the UK. It never had a colonial empire like Britain or France. 

Yet the global pizza market alone is worth $283 billion. That's more than the entire Japanese cuisine market ($18.9 billion) and Mexican cuisine market ($21.7 billion) combined. China's entire food industry: $587 billion, pizza alone: $283 billion. 

Google search data shows "pizza" dominates every other cuisine keyword globally. It's not just popular in Western markets; it's winning in China, India, and the Middle East.

I think there are three reasons this happened:

First, timing. Italian immigration (1880-1920) coincided perfectly with urbanization and the birth of the restaurant industry. When cities exploded, Italian immigrants opened restaurants with food that was easy to scale. Pizza needs flour, water, tomatoes, and cheese: ingredients you can source anywhere. Thai curry needs galangal, kaffir lime, lemongrass: none of which existed in most markets outside Southeast Asia.

Second, psychological design. Carbs, fat, and salt: the holy trinity of comfort food. It's not sophisticated enough to be intimidating, not exotic enough to be alienating. It occupies the perfect middle ground between "interesting" and "safe."

Third, franchising. Italian food wasn't spread by Italians: it was industrialized by American capitalism. Domino's, Pizza Hut, Papa John's aren't Italian companies. They're American franchises that turned Italian food into a scalable business model and distributed it through the most powerful system ever built.

The result? Italian food became the default. The thing groups order when they can't agree. The first cuisine kids eat when dining out.

Most cuisines spread through cultural proximity. Italian food spread because it removed every barrier to adoption. No complex ingredients. No acquired tastes. No religious restrictions.

That's why everyone has a favorite Italian restaurant. Mine is Fire and Ice in my hometown of Kathmandu, Nepal. The New York Times named it one of "15 of Our Readers' Favorite Pizza Places Around the World." Better Italian food than most places in Manhattan.

I analyzed 50,000 food delivery complaints.

The #2 reason customers leave 1-star reviews has nothing to do with food quality.

Soggy food kills more restaurants than bad recipes.

The problem: Restaurants think they're in the food business but they're also in the packaging business.

What goes wrong:
- Pizza boxes without proper ventilation create steam
- Soup containers that leak during transport
- Hot items placed next to cold items in the same bag

Zero thought given to 20-minute delivery windows

The secret successful chains know that packaging IS your brand experience.¬† 

When customers can't eat in your restaurant, the container becomes your dining room.

What winners do differently:
- Design containers for the journey, not just the kitchen
- Separate hot and cold items
- Use packaging as marketing (branded, Instagram-worthy boxes)
- Test every item after a 30-minute car ride

At the end of the day, your amazing burger becomes mediocre mush if it arrives soggy. 

Great food that travels badly loses to average food that travels well. Every single time.

I studied 500+ restaurants, and all of the successful restaurants had one thing in common: 

They are obsessed with the boring details.

- Checking food temps every 30 minutes
- Responding to every review within 24 hours
- Cleaning equipment the exact same way daily
- Training staff on portion control to the gram
- Double-checking every delivery bag before it leaves

What everyone else focuses on:

- Instagram-worthy decor

- Trendy marketing campaigns

Champions turn mundane tasks into unfair advantages. While rivals hunt viral moments, they master fundamentals.

McDonald's 32% Big Mac price increase since 2019 marks a historic acceleration, triple the rate of the previous decade.

From 2010 to 2019, Big Mac prices crept up just 13% (from $3.90 to $4.39). Then McDonald's accelerated: 32% increase from 2019 to 2025, pushing the Big Mac from $4.39 to $5.79. This pricing velocity shift triggered the first sustained traffic decline in over a decade.

The Breaking Point:

2019-2023: McDonald's raised prices steadily while maintaining 39.91% operating margins. Traffic held stable despite 20%+ annual hikes. Management repeatedly cited "pricing power" in earnings calls.

Q2 2024 marked the inflection point. Same-store sales turned negative (-1.0%) for the first time in 13 quarters. By Q1 2025, the decline accelerated to -3.6%, the worst performance since the pandemic. US traffic fell -2.6% year-over-year.

The recovery attempts in Q2-Q3 2025 (+2.5% same-store sales) came through value menu initiatives, yet traffic remains below pre-price-hike levels.

The Franchisee Crisis:

While corporate maintained pristine margins, the franchise system absorbed the shock. 30% of franchisees are now insolvent (Nomura Group, 2024). Operator cash flow down 10% from pandemic highs. Total system debt ballooned from $15B to $55.86B. The disconnect between corporate profitability and franchise viability widened to unsustainable levels.

Every major chain raised prices. Burger King increased 12.3%. Wendy's eliminated value offerings. Taco Bell doubled some items. Yet McDonald's suffers disproportionately. The difference? McDonald's built its empire on accessibility. Premium chains can justify premium pricing. McDonald's cannot escape its value positioning.

The core miscalculation: Management confused pandemic-era pricing tolerance with permanent pricing power. The 15-year data reveals the pattern, a decade of disciplined 1-2% annual increases from 2010-2019, then a dramatic acceleration post-pandemic. This pricing velocity shift destroyed the value perception McDonald's spent decades building.

The QSR sector demonstrates that pricing power remains context-dependent. McDonald's Q2-Q3 2025 recovery attempts through value initiatives show modest same-store sales gains, yet the fundamental challenge persists: rebuilding trust after breaking the value equation that defined the brand for decades.

It‚Äôs crazy that in the early 1980s, Ray Dalio worked to enable McDonald‚Äôs to sell the Chicken McNugget.

It took a bit of financial engineering from Dalio who would later go on to manage one of the world's largest hedge funds.

1Ô∏è‚É£ In 1982, McDonald‚Äôs wanted to launch McNuggets nationwide. But there was an issue ‚Äì Chicken prices swing wildly, and a spike could wipe out profits.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Suppliers wouldn‚Äôt allow fixed prices. Chicken producers wouldn‚Äôt commit to long-term contracts because feed costs (corn & soymeal) could rise and destroy their margins.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Enter Ray Dalio (yes, billionaire founder of the hedge fund Bridgewater Associates now managing $162B). At the time Bridgewater wasn‚Äôt even a hedge fund ‚Äì it was an advisory firm based in his Manhattan apartment.

Dalio brought a simple piece of financial engineering from the finance world ‚Äì futures contracts. Here‚Äôs how it worked:

1. Today: The farmer locks in a deal to pay $3.00 per bushel of chicken feed to be delivered 6 months from now.

2. Six months from now: The feed is delivered as promised under the deal

3. Even if prices are higher ($4, $5, or even $10 / bushel), the farmer still only pays the $3.00 they agreed to at the start.

4. The result: Their feed costs are stable, protecting them from sudden price spikes and making it easier to plan.

‚ÄúA chicken can be seen as a simple machine: a chick plus its feed,‚Äù Dalio recalled. ‚ÄúThe most volatile cost the producer needed to worry about was feed prices. I showed Lane [a chicken supplier] how to use a mix of corn and soymeal futures to lock in costs so they could quote a fixed price to McDonald‚Äôs. Having greatly reduced its price risk, McDonald‚Äôs introduced the McNugget in 1983. I felt great about helping make that happen.‚Äù

Here‚Äôs what that means in plain English: 

üí∞ Lane, the chicken supplier, bought futures contracts for corn at $3.00/bushel and soymeal at $250/ton.

üîÆ This locked in what they would pay for chicken feed months in advance, even if prices later rose to, say, $3.50/bushel and $300/ton.

üçó With feed costs guaranteed, Lane could offer McDonald‚Äôs a fixed price of, for example, $1.20 per pound of chicken.

üöÄ That stability let McDonald‚Äôs confidently roll out the McNugget in 1983 without worrying about sudden cost spikes.

4Ô∏è‚É£¬† Using corn & soymeal futures contracts, suppliers could lock in today‚Äôs prices for future delivery.
Example: Buy July corn futures at $3.00/bushel now ‚Äî even if the market hits $3.50, your cost stays $3.00.

5Ô∏è‚É£ With feed costs fixed, suppliers could safely offer McDonald‚Äôs a stable chicken price for the year ahead. In 1983: McNuggets launch nationwide.

Why did dollar menus disappear?

McDonald's launched the Dollar Menu in 2002. Everything was $1.

By 2013, Wendy's killed their 99-cent menu.

Today, McDonald's cheapest burger is $3.49.

Everyone blames labor costs and rent. They're not wrong‚Äîthose did rise. But they're always rising.

The structural shift was something else.

Fast food is 80-90% corn derivatives.

HFCS in your soda. Corn-fed beef in your burger. Corn oil in your fries.

The entire business model was built on cheap corn.

When corn prices jumped from $3.70/bushel in 2020 to $6.94 in 2022, the dollar menu economics broke.

I think there are three forces that created dollar menus, and then killed them:

First, government intervention.

The 1973 Farm Bill paid farmers to grow corn regardless of demand. Production exploded. Yields went from stable growth to 1.9 bushels per acre per year.

By 2010, the U.S. was producing 158.1 bushels per acre.

Corn got cheap. $2.17/bushel in 1973, $2.52 in 1990. Inflation-adjusted, corn was nearly free.

Second, industrial transformation.

Cheap corn got processed into three core inputs:

Coca-Cola switched to HFCS between 1980-1984. HFCS rapidly replaced sugar in soft drinks through the 1990s.

Corn-fed beef averaged $0.70/lb in the 1990s.

Corn oil became the default frying oil.

The entire fast food supply chain restructured around corn.

Third, the plateau.

Yields kept growing through 2010, but growth slowed after 2013.

Climate stress accelerated the problem. In 2023, 70% of corn areas were in drought.

Yields aren't collapsing, but they're not exploding anymore. Demand kept growing.

The result: corn prices surged 24.82% from 2020 to 2024.

Even after the 2022 spike settled, corn is still $4.20/bushel, 13.5% higher than 2020.

McDonald's launched the Dollar Menu when corn was structurally cheap. They're charging $3.49 now because corn is structurally expensive.

McDonald's added 1,130 US stores in 1995. They closed 244 in 2021. Growth at McDonald's has peaked.

US store count hit its ceiling at 14,350 in 2014, then fell to 13,438 by 2021. That's 912 net closures over seven years. 2021 alone saw 244 stores close.

Here's why:

75% of Americans live within 3 miles of a McDonald's. New stores mostly steal customers from existing ones.

Portfolio pruning became necessary. Hundreds of underperforming locations were closed. 

Strategy shifted from opening more stores to making more money from existing stores. McDonald's stopped building new locations and focused on digital ordering, drive-thru improvements, and delivery to boost sales at current restaurants.

Global growth moved overseas. Of McDonald's 10,000 new restaurants planned by 2027, only 900 are targeted for the US. 

Economic headwinds increased costs. California's $20/hour minimum wage and franchisee remodel expenses raised the threshold sales needed for new units to work financially.

Growth through new locations has limits. When you've conquered a market, innovation and optimization become the only path forward.

McDonald's didn't fail, they dominated so thoroughly that expansion became impossible. Become so successful there's no room to grow anymore.

A 66-year-old man was rejected by 1,009 restaurants before his pressure-cooked chicken recipe became the world's most valuable fast-food formula.

In 1952, Colonel Harland Sanders was broke. After "retiring" at 66, he decided to go into the "chicken business" with what he believed was the best fried chicken recipe in the world.

He started by offering local restaurants his recipe for just 5% of their increased chicken sales. No takers.

So he hit the road.

For two years, Sanders traveled town to town across America in his old car, pitching his secret recipe of 11 herbs and spices. At times he was so broke that he lived in his car.

But Sanders had a secret weapon: pressure cooking.

While other restaurants fried chicken the traditional way (taking 30+ minutes), Sanders' pressure-cooking method delivered crispy, juicy chicken in just 8-10 minutes. Same quality, 3x faster.

üçó Finally, in 1952, Pete Harman in South Salt Lake, Utah said yes. That handshake deal became the first KFC franchise.

From one successful franchise in Utah, Sanders built a franchising empire. His white linen suit and southern charm became the brand. 

üöÄ Today, KFC operates 18,000 locations across 118 countries. 

Sanders proved that persistence and resilience might not win today - but they always win eventually.

For millennials (like me), 2021-23 was their first serious tiff with inflation, having grown up through a relatively calm 2010s.

And for most people, restaurant prices are a daily reminder of how that affects your wallet.

The data speaks for itself:
‚ÄúFood away from home‚Äù prices rose 49.5% from 2014 to 2024 ‚Äì outpacing grocery inflation (+29.9%) and the overall CPI (+34.3%), per USDA and BLS data.

The steepest climb came in 2021‚Äì2022, when:

üí™ Labor costs jumped mid-single digits at many chains (Chipotle, Wendy‚Äôs).
‚ö°Ô∏è Energy and freight costs spiked.
ü•© Protein prices soared ‚Äì eggs and poultry from HPAI, beef from a tight cattle cycle, grains/oils from the war in Ukraine.

By 2023‚Äì2024, growth slowed (to ~4% annually) but stayed well above pre-COVID norms.

For operators, this was a balancing act:

üçü McDonald‚Äôs: After two years of price hikes, CEO Chris Kempczinski signaled 2024 pricing ‚Äúroughly in line‚Äù with easing inflation ‚Äì while leaning on bundles like the $5 Meal Deal to lure back low-income guests.

üåØ Chipotle: Held labor at ~25% of sales despite wage pressure, relying on steady pricing power and operational throughput.

üçî Burger King: Pulled the Whopper from core discounting and lifted price caps in 2022; returned to value plays in 2024 as traffic softened.

üçó Chick-fil-A: Privately held, but outside analyses show menu prices up 20-21% over 2022‚Äì23 on chicken and wage inflation.

Consumers noticed.
Value sensitivity rose sharply. Data shows traffic shifting from full-service to QSR. Deals, bundles, and ‚Äúeveryday value‚Äù menus staged a comeback in 2024 as operators sought to protect mix without eroding perception.

The new reality:
Even as commodity and freight costs normalize, wage rates and some inputs are structurally higher than in the 2010s. That means inflation is baking into the cost base.

Inflation reshaped U.S. restaurants over the last decade. If 2021-23 was about survival, 2024‚Äì25 is about recovery - with surgical pricing, operational efficiency, and value platforms at the core.

Despite inflation concerns, Americans are spending 53% of their food budget on restaurants, revealing a fundamental shift in how we value time and convenience.

From 1997 to 2023, Americans shifted 12 percentage points of their food spending from groceries to dining out from 41% to 53%. That shift pushed the restaurant industry to a record $1.1 trillion this year.

This trend accelerated during one of the most challenging periods for restaurants in decades.

From 2021-2024, customer visits dropped 10-20% from pre-pandemic levels. Menu prices soared 5.9% at quick-serve restaurants and 7.1% at full-service establishments. Supply chain disruptions and labor costs squeezed margins everywhere.

Cooking at home costs $4.31 per meal while dining out costs about 48% more. Restaurant price inflation (3.6%) is running double grocery inflation (1.8%) in 2024.

Yet Americans continue choosing restaurants over home cooking for rational economic reasons.

Two-earner households, now 49.6% of married couples, spend $3,228 annually on dining out versus $2,664 for single-income families. When both partners work, time becomes more valuable than money.

Americans spend 53 minutes per day preparing food at home. For dual-income families earning $75,000+ annually, that hour represents $36+ in opportunity cost. Restaurants aren't just selling food, they're selling back valuable time.

The killer pattern: When 60-70% of complaints mention food quality or taste, the restaurant is doomed.

Complaints about service, wait times, or atmosphere can be fixed. 

What I look for:
"Food was bland/tasteless"
"Worst meal I've ever had"
"Don't waste your money"

The exception: Late-night spots and fried chicken places. They survive terrible reviews because they fill a need (open 24/7, little competition). 

But even they could explode their revenue with better reviews.

What successful restaurants do differently:¬†
They obsess over food consistency. They read every review. They fix recipes based on feedback.

The brutal reality: You can have the best location, beautiful decor, and perfect service. 

But if your food (and rating) sucks, you're dead.

Cava: $12.9B peak ‚Üí $7.4B today. Sweetgreen: $5.5B IPO ‚Üí $1B today.

Both companies were positioned as the future of fast-casual dining. Investors poured money into the "healthy food revolution" narrative.

Cava hit its peak market cap of $12.9 billion in December 2024. Today it's worth $7.4 billion. That's a 43% decline in less than a year, despite being profitable.

Sweetgreen's collapse is even more dramatic. From a $5.5 billion IPO valuation in 2021 to under $1 billion today. An 82% decline from its peak.

Here's what the data reveals:

Cava operates 398 stores generating $964 million in revenue. Operating margin: 6.22%. Profitable, but barely scaled.

Sweetgreen runs 246 stores with $677 million in revenue. Operating margin: -13.51%. Still losing money after years of expansion.

Compare that to Chipotle: 3,726 stores, $11.3 billion revenue, proven unit economics that work at scale.

The market correction wasn't about the companies failing. It was about valuations finally matching reality.

Cava's same-store sales grew 13.4% in 2024. Strong performance. But growth doesn't justify any valuation when the market turns.

Sweetgreen's 6% same-store sales growth shows the salad concept has fundamental scaling challenges. Healthy food is niche. Burritos are universal.

Both companies will survive and likely thrive as businesses. But investors learned a painful lesson about the difference between a good restaurant and a good restaurant stock.

The "next Chipotle" narrative is dangerous. There's only one Chipotle, and it took decades to build.

I was chatting with one of the country's largest franchisee operator groups who shared an interesting perspective about online ratings that often gets overlooked: rating expectations actually differ quite a bit depending on the type of restaurant.

If you're leading marketing efforts, here's what to focus on:
1. Compare your ratings with direct competitors in your category
2. Set achievable rating targets based on your restaurant type
3. Create review management strategies that fit your segment

Why Cava is worth billions but your local restaurant struggles: assembly lines vs. cooking.

Here's what you see at Cava:
- Pre-cut vegetables in measured portions
- Staff following exact assembly protocols
- Zero cooking decisions or creativity
- Standardized portions down to the gram
- Same experience in every location

Here's what happens at your local restaurant:
- Chef decides seasoning levels daily
- Portion sizes vary by cook
- "A little extra" or "light on the sauce"
- Different results every time
- Creativity and variation

Cava model:
- Hires quickly, train in 2 days
- No culinary skills required
- Predictable food costs
- Scalable to 1,000+ locations
- Consistent profit margins

Local restaurant model:
- Hire experienced cooks slowly
- Long training periods
- Variable food costs
- Chef creativity = cost variations
- Margins depend on who's cooking

This is why franchises dominate: McDonald's, Chipotle, Subway sell assembly-line consistency, not just food.

The most successful "restaurants" eliminated cooking entirely. They're manufacturing operations with customer-facing assembly.

Your local chef's creativity is most often their competitive disadvantage. Every variation costs money, creates inconsistency, and makes scaling impossible.
